children.name: ask
children.definition: hỏi
examples: ▪ If you have any questions, don’t be afraid to ask.
▪ For information about the new drug, ask your doctor.
questioner[C] British: người hỏi
▪ A questioner in the studio audience asked the Labour MP to defend his party’s recent statement.

children.name: ask (sb) about sth
examples: ▪ They’ll probably just ask you about your education and work experience.

children.name: ask (sb) a question
examples: ▪ At the end of the presentation you’ll all have a chance to ask questions.

children.name: ask (sb) if/whether
examples: ▪ I was a little surprised when he asked me if I was married.

children.name: ask (sb) what/how/why etc
examples: ▪ What should I tell people if they ask me why you didn’t come to the party?

children.name: pose
children.definition: đặt ra , đưa ra
examples: pose a questionto ask a question, especially one that needs to be carefully thought about :
Can we go back to the question that Helena posed earlier?
In her book she poses the question ‘How much do we need to be happy?’.

children.name: want to know
children.definition: to ask sth - use this especially when you are reporting what sb else has asked:muốn biết
examples: ‘Why didn’t you write to me?’ Barbara wanted to know.
The policeman wanted to know their names, but they wouldn’t tell him.

children.name: want to know about
examples: Everybody in the office wanted to know about my trip.

children.name: want to know where/how/why etc
examples: Jason wants to know where you keep the kitchen scissors.

children.name: inquire
children.definition: /enquireUK  formal to ask sb for information about sth, especially sb whose job is to know about it: hỏi thăm
examples: ‘Why are you doing that?’ the boy inquired.

children.name: sound out
children.definition: to find out what sb thinks about your plan or idea by asking them questions, especially because you want their help or support: thăm dò ý kiến ai
examples: I think she’ll like the idea, but you’d better sound her out first.
Before launching the project, they sounded out a number of leading experts.

children.name: sound out about/on
examples: The board of directors have sounded him out about taking the CEO position.

children.name: put sb on the spot
children.definition: to deliberately ask sb a question that they finddifficultorembarrassingto answer: gây khó dễ choa i
examples: The reporter’s questions were clearly designed to put the Senator on the spot.
I don’t want to put you on the spot, but I’m really curious about how you know Tim.
Mira rather put the boss on the spot by asking him when he was going to give us a pay-rise.

children.name: sth that you ask sb for info
question
children.definition: sth that you ask sb, either when speaking or when writing :
examples: Can I ask you a question?
I’m afraid I can’t answer that question.

children.name: ask
children.definition: sb
examples: a questionDon’t be afraid to ask questions.

children.name: have a question
children.definition: want to ask a question
examples: I just have one question: is the treatment effective?

children.name: pose a questionformal
children.definition: ask a question
examples: He poses the question, ‘What should we teach our children?’

children.name: put a question to somebody
children.definition: ask a question in a formal situation
examples: I recently put some of these questions to a psychologist.

children.name: answer a question
examples: You haven’t answered my question.

children.name: avoid/evade/dodge a question
children.definition: not give a direct answer
examples: He had skilfully evaded Margie’s questions.

children.name: set a question
children.definition: invent a question for a test
examples: He used to set the questions for a TV quiz show.

children.name: rephrase a question
children.definition: ask it in a different way
examples: He didn’t answer, so I rephrased my question.

children.name: bombard somebody with questions
children.definition: ask someone a lot of questions
examples: They bombarded him with questions about the case.

children.name: field questions
children.definition: answer a lot of questions
examples: He fielded questions from reporters about the announcement.

children.name: difficult/hard
examples: Some of the questions in the last section were very difficult.

children.name: easy
examples: These questions should be easy for you.

children.name: a good question
children.definition: interesting or difficult to answer
examples: That’s a good question.

children.name: a stupid/silly question
children.definition: one whose answer is obvious
examples: Did you win, or is that a stupid question?

children.name: an awkward question
children.definition: one that someone does not want to answer
examples: How can we keep the press from asking awkward questions?

children.name: a tricky/tough question
children.definition: one that is difficult to answer
examples: That’s a really tricky question.

children.name: an embarrassing question
examples: The media began to ask embarrassing questions about MPs' expenses.

children.name: a personal question
children.definition: a question relating to someone’s private life
examples: Can I ask you a personal question?

children.name: a simple question
children.definition: one that is easy to answer
examples: All you have to do is answer the three simple questions below.

children.name: a searching/probing question
children.definition: one designed to find things out
examples: The immigration officer asked me some searching questions.

children.name: a direct question
children.definition: one that asks for information in a very direct way
examples: She was startled by the direct question.

children.name: an exam/a test question
examples: You have to answer twenty exam questions.

children.name: an impertinent question
children.definition: one which you have no right to ask
examples: She did not answer the maid’s impertinent question.

children.name: a rhetorical question
children.definition: a question you ask without expecting an answer, in order to make a point

children.name: a multiple choice question
children.definition: where you are given a set of possible answers

children.name: question about/on
examples: They asked me quite a lot of difficult questions about my job.
The survey included questions on age and smoking habits.

children.name: in answer to sb’s question
examples: In answer to your last question, ‘Yes’.

children.name: inquiry
children.definition: /enquiryUK  a question you ask in order to getinformationor find out thedetailsabout something:thăm vấn, dò xét
examples: inquiry about
We’re getting a lot of inquiries about our new London–Rio service.
inquiry from
inquiries from potential applicants
help the police with their inquiriesBritish English(= to answer questions about a crime )

children.name: make an inquiry
examples: The police are making inquiries to discover the cause of the accident.

children.name: get/have an inquiry
children.definition: receive it
examples: We’ve already had a lot of inquiries about membership of the new sports centre.

children.name: receive an inquiryformal
examples: The television station has received several inquiries from viewers requesting a repeat of the programme.

children.name: handle/deal with an inquiry
examples: Staff will be available to deal with inquiries.

children.name: answer an inquiry
children.definition: alsorespond to an inquiryformal
examples: The government has not yet answered our inquiry.

children.name: a general inquiry
examples: There is a need for a general inquiry into the train company’s safety standards.

children.name: a specific inquiry
examples: His job is to answer specific inquiries by individuals or groups.

children.name: a written inquiry
examples: I submitted a written inquiry to the local council.

children.name: a flood/stream of inquiries
examples: The special offer has produced a flood of inquiries from interested customers.

children.name: loaded question
children.definition: loaded/ leading question a question that deliberatelytrickssb, so that they give you the answer that you want or say sth that they do not intend to say:câu hỏi bẫy
examples: You don’t expect me to answer a loaded question like that, do you?
The jurors said interviewers used leading questions and coached the children on how they should answer.

children.name: trick question
children.definition: a question that seems easy to answer but hasa hidden difficulty: câu hỏi mẹo
examples: ‘Did you have a good time while I was gone?’ ‘That’s a trick question, right? If I say yes, you’ll be angry that I didn’t miss you.’

children.name: ask around
children.definition: to ask several people, especially peoplethat you know, in order to get information from them: hỏi xung quanh, hỏi dạo xem
examples: I’m not sure where you can find a babysitter - I’ll ask around.

children.name: ask around about
examples: Stephen’s been asking around about the best places to go in the evenings.

children.name: make inquiries
children.definition: /make enquiriesUK  to try to get information about sth by asking several people,especially people whose job is to know about it:điều tra, dò hỏi
examples: After making a few inquiries, we decided not to hire her.

children.name: make inquiries about
examples: We graduate next month and most of my classmates are already making enquiries about jobs.
The bank made inquiries about her financial situation before agreeing to the loan.

children.name: poll
children.definition: the process of finding out what people think about something by asking many people the same question, or the record of the result: cuộc thăm dò ý kiến, bảng thăm dò ý kiên
examples: According to the polls, a huge majority of citizens oppose bilingual education.
A recent poll found that 80% of Californians support the governor.
The latestpublic opinion pollshowed that 25% of us consider ourselves superstitious.
poll on
a poll on eating habits
poll of
a poll of 1,000 people
A poll of 700 female registered voters found that 56% favor full abortion rights.
Nearly 60% of the voters who were polled did not recognize Bronson’s name.
For its study the company polled 150 randomly selected physicians.

children.name: carry out/take/do a poll
examples: A similar poll was carried out among academics in the United States.|A poll taken last month gave the Democrats a seven-point lead.

children.name: conduct a pollformal
children.definition: carry out a poll
examples: The poll was conducted with a sample of 1,023 adults.

children.name: a poll shows/indicates/suggests sth
examples: Polls show that older voters are most concerned about economic issues.

children.name: a poll finds sth
examples: Our poll found that 29 percent rated his performance as good.

children.name: poll results/findings
examples: The poll results are very encouraging.

children.name: a poll rating
children.definition: showing how popular someone is
examples: His poll ratings keep slipping.

children.name: an opinion poll
children.definition: that measures what people think about something
examples: A recent opinion poll showed strong support for the government.

children.name: an exit poll
children.definition: when people are asked how they have just voted
examples: The exit polls said that 46 percent of women had voted for Obama.

children.name: a popularity poll
children.definition: measuring how popular someone is
examples: In most popularity polls, he is in fourth or fifth place.

children.name: a local/national/statewide etc poll
examples: Local polls show him leading by only two or three points.

children.name: sb’s lead in the polls
examples: Labour soon regained its lead in the polls.

children.name: sb’s standing in the polls
children.definition: how popular a poll shows them to be
examples: The President's standing in the polls declined sharply.

children.name: be ahead/leading in the polls
examples: The good news is that we are ahead in the polls.

children.name: be behind/trailing in the polls
examples: At the moment the Democrats are trailing in the polls.

children.name: poll[
examples: T] to ask a lot of people a set of questions about a subject that isimportantto the public, especiallypolitics, in order to find out the general opinion about it:

children.name: canvass
children.definition: to go to the houses of a lot of people or phone a lot of people up in order to find out their political opinions or to get their political support:điều tra ý kiến dân (trước bầu cử)
examples: Party members were out canvassing as soon as the election was announced.
We canvassed over half the constituency by phone or text-message.

children.name: survey
children.definition: an attempt to find out people’s opinions, the way they live, what they like and dislike etc, by asking a large number of people a set of questions: cuộc khảo sát
examples: survey of
According to a survey of 606 city residents, garbage collection was the city service people liked most.
a survey of US businesses
survey on
Many parents were surprised by the survey on teenage drug use.
survey[T] C1 to ask a lot of people a set of questions about their opinions, the way they live, what they like and dislike etc in order to find out general opinions: khảo sát điều tra
A large segment of the population that was surveyed was taking vitamin supplements.
Researchers surveyed 10,000 customers about the quality of companies that they used.
The researchers surveyed the attitudes of 2500 college students.
Many of the listeners surveyed said that they were not satisfied with the station's programmes.

children.name: carry out/do a survey
examples: The survey was carried out by Warwick University.

children.name: conduct a surveyformal
children.definition: do a survey
examples: a survey conducted by the British Medical Association.

children.name: a survey shows/reveals something
examples: Our survey showed that many women are afraid to go out alone at night.

children.name: a survey finds something
examples: A survey found that 37 percent of students were born outside the country.

children.name: a survey suggests something
examples: Recent surveys suggest that these are the foreign languages most in demand by employers.

children.name: a recent/new survey
examples: According to a recent survey, students buy an average of 11.33 books a year for their courses.

children.name: an annual survey
examples: Every council will be required to conduct an annual survey of residents.

children.name: a national survey
examples: A national survey revealed that one in four 15-year-olds smokes regularly.

children.name: an extensive survey
examples: We conducted an extensive survey asking patients to suggest ways in which the service could be improved.

children.name: a detailed survey
examples: The author carried out a detailed survey of 32 organizations in Japan and Korea.

children.name: an opinion survey
examples: Opinion surveys showed consistently that unemployment remained a matter of concern.

children.name: a customer survey
examples: They have begun to listen carefully to their customers, through customer surveys, focus groups, etc.

children.name: the results of a survey
examples: The results of the survey have not yet been analysed.

children.name: questionnaire
children.definition: a written set of questions which you give to a large number of people in order to collect information: bảng câu hỏi
examples: Of nearly 5,000 questionnaires that were sent out, only 428 were returned.
The questionnaire asks students how they feel about services on campus.

children.name: fill in/fill out/complete a questionnaire(= answer all the questions in it )
examples: All staff were asked to fill in a questionnaire about their jobs.
Please complete the questionnaire and return it in the envelope provided.

children.name: form
children.definition: an official document with spaces where you write information, especially about yourself : mẫu đơn
examples: Make sure you sign and date the form before you return it.

children.name: application forma form with questions you must answer if you want a job, a chance to study etc
examples: Application formsare available from the college.
The visa requires an application form and two photos.

children.name: entry form(= document used to enter a competition)
examples: Justcompletetheentry formand return it.

children.name: fill in/fill out/ complete a form(= write the answers to the questions on a form )
examples: Fill in the form and send it back with your cheque.
When you havecompletedthe form, hand it in at the desk.

children.name: to ask sb questions to decide whether to offer them a job etc
interview
children.definition: to ask sb a lot of questions as part of a formal process, so that you can decide whether they are suitable for a job, a chance to study at a college etc:phỏng vấn
examples: I’ll be interviewing two candidates today and three others tomorrow.
All prospective students are interviewed by alumni before a final decision is made.
interview sb for a job/post etc
We’ve interviewed a woman for the job already, but she wasn’t very well qualified.
interviewing[U]
interviewing skills

children.name: interview
children.definition: a formal meeting at which sb is asked questions in order to find out whether they are suitable for a job, course of study etc : phỏng vấn
examples: I always get nervous before interviews.
Ron’s going to Tufts University next week for an interview and a tour of the campus.
interview for
an interview for a job on the Los Angeles Times
a portfolio of work presentedat interview

children.name: have an interview
examples: She has an interview next week for a teaching job in Paris.

children.name: go for an interview
children.definition: alsoattend an interviewformal
examples: I went for an interview at a software company yesterday.

children.name: get an interview
examples: He was one of only five people to get an interview out of more than 100 people who applied.

children.name: be called/invited for
children.definition: an
examples: interviewApplicants who are called for interview may be asked to have a medical exam.

children.name: do an interview
children.definition: alsoconduct an interviewformal
examples: The interview was conducted in French.

children.name: give somebody an interview
children.definition: interview someone
examples: We gave her an interview, but decided not to offer her the job.

children.name: a job interview
examples: Try to predict the questions you might get in your job interview.

children.name: an informal/formal interview
examples: Applicants will normally have an informal interview with the manager.|One out of every six candidates reached the formal interview.

children.name: the first interview
children.definition: alsothe preliminary interviewformal
examples: He felt the first interview had gone well.

children.name: a second/follow-up interview
children.definition: a more detailed interview after you have been successful in a previous interview
examples: She was asked back for a second interview.

children.name: a mock interview
children.definition: one that you do for practice, rather than a real interview
examples: Mock interviews are one way in which students can improve their job-seeking skills.

children.name: a face-to-face interview
children.definition: in which people meet in person
examples: I had to do a face-to-face interview followed by an entry test.

children.name: a telephone interview
examples: The first stage is a telephone interview.

children.name: interview technique
examples: The book gives some useful advice on interview technique.

children.name: an interview question
examples: Some of the interview questions were quite difficult to answer.

children.name: the interview panel
children.definition: the group of people interviewing someone
examples: The interview panel were very impressed with her enthusiasm.

children.name: to ask sb questions for a newspaper, etc
interview
children.definition: an occasion when a famous person is asked questions about their life, experiences, or opinions for a newspaper, magazine, television programme etc : buổi phỏng vấn
examples: During a recent interview Rohr said the renovations will cost $38 million.
exclusive interview(= one that is given to only one newspaper, programme etc )
interview with
an interview with the president
An interview with the actress appears in next week’s ‘People’ magazine.
TV/radio/newspaper interview
In his latest TV interview the lead singer talks about his drug problem.
Ina television interview last night she denied she had any intention of resigning.
give an interviewallow someone to interview you cho phép phỏng vấn
The new Prime Minister gave his first full-length TV interview last night.
Elton Johngaveaninterview toBarbara Walters(= he answered her questions ).

children.name: interview
children.definition: to ask a famous person questions about their life, experiences, or opinions for a newspaper, magazine, television programme etc phỏng vấn
examples: At the end of the race the winner was interviewed by NBC news.
She has interviewed celebrities and political leaders on her radio programme for over 25 years.

children.name: to ask sb a lot of questions
question
children.definition: to ask sb a lot of questions, in order to get information about sth such as a crime or find out what they think: tra hỏi
examples: Two men have been arrested and questioned.
We all wondered where Sylvia got the money, but no one dared question her.
The police questioned him for three hours before releasing him without charge.
When questioned by reporters, he denied all knowledge about the affair.
questioner[C] người hỏi
Jim Lehrer was the only questioner of the candidates in the debate.

children.name: question sb about sth
examples: Liz was very well informed and questioned me about the political situation in Africa.

children.name: question sb closelycarefully, asking a lot of difficult questions tra hỏi kĩ càng ai đó
examples: The interviewer questioned Miss Jarvis closely about her computer experience.

children.name: fire questions at
children.definition: fire/shoot questions at to ask sba lotof questions veryquicklyin order toconfusethem or make themadmitto sth: tra vấn
examples: The lawyer fired questions at me so quickly I didn’t have time to think.
The teacher kept shooting questions at the frightened girls until they confessed everything.

children.name: grill
children.definition: /give sb a grillingUK  informal to ask sb a lot ofdifficultquestions in order to make themexplain their actions, plans, or opinions,in a way that is tiring or annoying: tra hỏi, “nướng, thiêu đốt”
examples: ▪ I stood in the hall and listened as the interviewers grilled the next candidate.
▪ Hilda’s teacher gave her a real grilling about why she’d missed so many classes.
grilling[C]
▪ The meeting turned out to be a grilling by Democrats of the Republican senator about his proposal.

children.name: grill sb about/on sth
examples: ▪ Maxine started grilling me on why I’d been spending so much time alone.

children.name: give sb the third degree
children.definition: informal to ask someone a lot of difficult questions in order tomake them explain their actions, plans, or opinions:tra hỏi, “tra tấn”
examples: I was just out with friends - you don’t have to give me the third degree.
Whenever one of my boyfriends came to the house, Dad would give them the third degree.

children.name: pump
children.definition: sb for to ask sb a lot of questions about a particular subject or event in order to get as muchinformationas possible: moi móc

children.name: pump sb for information/details
examples: Viktor sat with Vassily and me and pumped me for information about hockey teams.
He wants to pump Jody for the details of some job her company is advertising.

children.name: pick sb’s brains
children.definition: to ask sb for information about sthbecause you think they know more about it than you:
examples: You know all about tax law - can I pick your brains for a minute?
The workshop is designed so that new managers canpick the brains ofmanagers with more experience.

children.name: quiz
children.definition: to ask sb a lot of questions, especiallybecause you want to find out what they have been doing, and often in a way that annoys them:căn vặn, tra hỏi
examples: When Stan eventually came home from the party, his wife quizzed him for hours.

children.name: quiz sb about/on sth
examples: My parents never stop quizzing me about where I go at night.
Reporters quizzed the President on tax policy and Central America.

children.name: interrogate
children.definition: to ask sb a lot of questions for a long time in order to get information, sometimes using threatsSYN question: tra hỏi
examples: The police interrogated the suspect for several hours.
He was interrogated by US agents about his alleged links to al-Qaeda.

children.name: if you like
children.definition: a)used to suggest or offer something to someone :
examples: I can give you her phone number, if you like.
If you like, I could go with you.
We can leave now if you like.
b)used to agree to something, even if it is not really what you want yourself :

children.name: ‘Shall we get a takeaway on the way home?’ ‘If you like.’
examples: c)used to suggest one possible way of describing something or someone :
We don’t have a proper agreement, but we have an informal understanding, if you like.
I'm not sure if I have the confidence, the nerve if you like (= if this phrase is suitable) , to apply for the job.
